item.title: Creative ways to fund open source projects
item.description: “Open source maintenance fee” trialed by Wix Toolset, while the creator of uv offers paid, enterprise-only features for larger companies.

item.title: New trend: extreme hours at AI startups
item.description: Pulling 80+ hour work weeks – including weekends – is becoming the norm across AI startups, and is unlikely to stop while AI is so hot.

item.title: Cursor makes developers less effective?
item.description: A study into the workflows of experienced developers found that devs who use Cursor for bugfixes are around 19% slower than devs who use no AI tools at all. One possible takeaway is that AI tools can be harder work than we’re led to believe.

item.title: The Pulse: Section 174 is reversed! Mostly, that is
item.description: Finally, relief: tax regulation hurting the US tech industry is striked off for good - for the most part, that is.

item.title: Software engineering with LLMs in 2025: temperature check
item.description:
How are devs using AI tools at Big Tech and startups, and what do they actually think of them? This was the topic of my annual conference talk, in June 2025, in London, at LDX3 by LeadDev.

To research, I talked with devs at:

  • AI

item.title: Builder.ai did not “fake AI with 700 engineers”
item.description: The claim that the AI startup “faked AI” with hundreds of engineers went viral – and I also fell for it, initially. The reality is much more sobering: Builder.ai built a code generator on top of Claude and other LLMs; it did not build a so-called “Mechanical Turk.”

item.title: Stack overflow is almost dead
item.description: Today, Stack overflow has almost as few questions asked per month, as when it launched back in 2009. A recap of its slow, then rapid, downfall.

item.title: Tech hiring: is this an inflection point?
item.description: We might be seeing the end of remote coding interviews as we know them, and a return of in-person interviews, trial days and longer trial periods. Could hiring be returning to pre-pandemic norms?

item.title: Survey: What’s in your tech stack?
item.description: We want to capture an accurate snapshot of software engineering, today – and need your help! Tell us about your tech stack and get early access to the final report, plus extra analysis

item.title: Software engineering job openings hit five-year low?
item.description: There are 35% fewer software developer job listings on Indeed today, than five years ago. Compared to other industries, job listings for software engineers grew much more in 2021-2022, but have declined much faster since. A look into possible reasons for this, and what could come next.

item.title: Where did TikTok’s software engineers go?
item.description: How has this uncertainty affected software engineers at the Chinese-owned social network?

item.title: The Pragmatic Engineer 100K Giveaway
item.description:
The Pragmatic Engineer's YouTube channel crossed 100K subscribers. Celebrating with a giveaway of 100 books and newsletter subs:

  • 10x signed physical books (The Software Engineer’s Guidebook [in English or German - your choice!], Building Mobile Apps at Scale; winners get both; shipping is on me)
  • 90x

item.title: Are LLMs making StackOverflow irrelevant?
item.description: Fresh data shows that the number of questions asked on StackOverflow are as low as they were back in 2009 – which was when StackOverflow was one years old. The drop suggests that ChatGPT – and LLMs – managed to make StackOverflow’s business model irrelevant in about two years’ time.

item.title: Where to find to The Pragmatic Engineer Podcast
item.description:
The Pragmatic Engineer Podcast covers software engineering at Big Tech and startups, from the inside. We do deepdives with experienced engineers and tech professionals who share their hard-earned lessons, interesting stories and advice they have on building software.

After each episode, you’ll walk away with pragmatic approaches you

item.title: Why my new audiobook “The Software Engineer's Guidebook” is everywhere except on Audible
item.description: Currently, Audible’s position is hurting audiobook authors. My audiobook isn’t on Audible due to a mix of their monopolistic pricing practices, and the company’s own complacency in how long they take to approve new titles.
